head.title: Headaches, With and Without the Pain

hedline.hl1: Headaches, With and Without the Pain

abstract.p: Nasal stuffiness, droopy eyelid and contraction of the pupil, all symptoms of cluster headache, are reported in a man who had no pain but who six years later experiences the same symptoms, but this time with severe pain; case indicates that symptoms are not, as many believe, a response to the pain of cluster headache, but symptoms in their own right; drawing (S)

block.p: A headache without the head pain might sound contradictory, but the condition, described in a new journal article, could lend insights into an ailment known as the cluster headache.
Doctors writing in yesterday's issue of Neurology described the case of a 22-year-old man who had all the symptoms of a cluster headache, except the pain.
A headache without the head pain might sound contradictory, but the condition, described in a new journal article, could lend insights into an ailment known as the cluster headache.
Doctors writing in yesterday's issue of Neurology described the case of a 22-year-old man who had all the symptoms of a cluster headache, except the pain.
When he went to his doctor, he exhibited nasal stuffiness, a droopy eyelid and contraction of one of his pupils, all signs of the painful condition that affects about 1 in 1,000 people, mostly men.
The patient said he suffered one to three attacks a day, each lasting an hour or two. After six weeks, the symptoms disappeared.
But six years later, the article said, the man came back.
This time, he had the same symptoms, but also severe pain that lasted 90 minutes, about twice a day.
When he was treated with a drug used for cluster headaches, sumatriptan, the pain and most of his other symptoms went away.
''This report may guide future cluster headache research in another direction,'' the author, Dr. Rolf Salvesen of the University of Tromso in Norway, said in a statement.
His patient's condition offers evidence that tearing, congestion and drooping eye associated with cluster headaches are not, as many believed, a response to the pain, but symptoms in their own right.
